messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 63 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Discreteness of asymptotic tensor ranks

Paper Abstract: Abstract Tensor parameters that are amortized or regularized over large tensor powers, often called ‚Äúasymptotic‚Äù tensor parameters, play a central role in several areas including algebraic complexity theory (constructing fast matrix multiplication algorithms), quantum information (entanglement cost and distillable entanglement), and additive combinatorics (bounds on cap sets, sunflower-free sets, etc.). Examples are the asymptotic tensor rank, asymptotic slice rank and asymptotic subrank. Recent works (Costa‚ÄìDalai, Blatter‚ÄìDraisma‚ÄìRupniewski, Christandl‚ÄìGesmundo‚ÄìZuiddam) have investigated notions of discreteness (no accumulation points) or ‚Äúgaps‚Äù in the values of such tensor parameters. We prove a general discreteness theorem for asymptotic tensor parameters of order-three tensors and use this to prove that (1) over any finite field (and in fact any finite set of coefficients in any field), the asymptotic subrank and the asymptotic slice rank have no accumulation points, and (2) over the complex numbers, the asymptotic slice rank has no accumulation points. Central to our approach are two new general lower bounds on the asymptotic subrank of tensors, which measures how much a tensor can be diagonalized. The first lower bound says that the asymptotic subrank of any concise three-tensor is at least the cube-root of the smallest dimension. The second lower bound says that any concise three-tensor that is ‚Äúnarrow enough‚Äù (has one dimension much smaller than the other two) has maximal asymptotic subrank. Our proofs rely on new lower bounds on the maximum rank in matrix subspaces that are obtained by slicing a three-tensor in the three different directions. We prove that for any concise tensor, the product of any two such maximum ranks must be large, and as a consequence there are always two distinct directions with large max-rank.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 63 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 63"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Optimal superdense coding of entangled states",
        "Limits on the universal method for matrix multiplication",
        "Generalized polynomial identities and pivotal monomials",
        "A refined laser method and faster matrix multiplication",
        "On cap sets and the group-theoretic approach to matrix multiplication",
        "Matrix multiplication via matrix groups",
        "Algebraic complexity theory, volume 315 of Grundlehren der mathematischen Wissenschaften",
        "Countably many asymptotic tensor ranks",
        "A tensor restriction theorem over finite fields",
        "Geometric complexity theory and tensor rank",
        "Slice rank of block tensors and irreversibility of structure tensors of algebras",
        "Fast Matrix Multiplication",
        "A gap in the slice rank of kùëòk-tensors",
        "A gap in the subrank of tensors",
        "Counterexamples to additivity of minimum output pùëùp-R√©nyi entropy for pùëùp close to 0",
        "Ranks derived from multilinear maps",
        "Group-theoretic algorithms for matrix multiplication",
        "Structure vs. randomness for bilinear maps",
        "Partition and analytic rank are equivalent over large fields",
        "On the dimension of subspaces with bounded Schmidt rank",
        "Skew fields, volume 57 of Encyclopedia of Mathematics and its Applications. Theory of general division rings",
        "A group-theoretic approach to fast matrix multiplication",
        "Fast matrix multiplication using coherent configurations",
        "Barriers for fast matrix multiplication from irreversibility",
        "Universal points in the asymptotic spectrum of tensors",
        "Matrix multiplication via arithmetic progressions",
        "The G-stable rank for tensors and the cap set problem",
        "Sur une g√©n√©ralisation du groupe orthogonal √† quatre variables",
        "A probabilistic remark on algebraic program testing",
        "On non-commutative rank and tensor rank",
        "Subrank and Optimal Reduction of Scalar Multiplications to Generic Tensors",
        "Faster matrix multiplication via asymmetric hashing",
        "On large subsets of with no three-term arithmetic progression",
        "On spaces of linear transformations with bounded rank",
        "Commutative/noncommutative rank of linear matrices and subspaces of matrices of low rank",
        "Linear forms and higher-degree uniformity for functions on ùêÖpnsubscriptsuperscriptùêÖùëõùëù\\mathbf{F}^{n}_{p}",
        "The next gap in the subrank of 3-tensors",
        "Entanglement in random subspaces",
        "Aspects of generic entanglement",
        "On the structure of cubic and quartic polynomials",
        "Geometric Rank of Tensors and Subrank of Matrix Multiplication",
        "The growth rate of tri-colored sum-free sets",
        "Powers of tensors and fast matrix multiplication",
        "Equations for secant varieties of Veronese and other varieties",
        "The analytic rank of tensors and its applications",
        "On the maximal rank in a subspace of matrices",
        "Locally linearly dependent operators and reflexivity of operator spaces",
        "Multipartite entanglement in 2√ó2√ón22ùëõ2\\times{}2\\times{}n quantum systems",
        "Upper bounds for sunflower-free sets",
        "On the maximal dimension of a completely entangled subspace for finite level quantum systems",
        "Fast probabilistic algorithms for verification of polynomial identities",
        "Notes on the ‚Äúslice rank‚Äù of tensors",
        "Gaussian elimination is not optimal",
        "Relative bilinear complexity and matrix multiplication",
        "The asymptotic spectrum of tensors",
        "Degeneration and complexity of bilinear maps: some asymptotic spectra",
        "A symmetric formulation of the Croot-Lev-Pach-Ellenberg-Gijswijt capset bound",
        "Spezialisierung und degeneration von tensoren",
        "An unentangled Gleason‚Äôs theorem",
        "Entanglement polytopes: multiparticle entanglement from single-particle information",
        "New bounds for matrix multiplication: from alpha to omega",
        "Asymptotic spectra: Theory, applications and extensions",
        "Probabilistic algorithms for sparse polynomials"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 63 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Discreteness of asymptotic tensor ranks, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
